## 판결문 요약


315 N.E.2d 729 (1974)
Leon PETTYJOHN, Appellant (Petitioner below),
v.
STATE of Indiana, Appellee (Respondent below).
No. 2-1073A218.
Court of Appeals of Indiana, Second District.
September 5, 1974.
Harriette Bailey Conn, Public Defender, Darrell F. Ellis, Deputy Public Defender, Indianapolis, for appellant.
Theodore L. Sendak, Atty. Gen., Henry O. Stitler, Deputy Atty. Gen., Indianapolis, for appellee.
BUCHANAN, Judge.

CASE SUMMARY
Petitioner-Appellant Leon Pettyjohn (Pettyjohn) appeals from the trial court's denial of his Petition for Post-Conviction Relief, claiming his guilty plea was not voluntarily and knowingly entered.
We affirm.

FACTS
On June 29, 1967, Pettyjohn was indicted for First Degree Murder and entered a plea of not guilty at his arraignment on August 23, 1967. Subsequently, on December *730 11, 1967, Pettyjohn and two co-defendants appeared with counsel and indicated to the trial court that they wished to withdraw their previously entered pleas and plead guilty to lesser charges. Pettyjohn then entered a plea of guilty to Manslaughter.[1]
Prior to accepting their guilty pleas the trial court carefully examined each of the defendants, informing them of the nature of, and the punishment for, the crime to which they were pleading guilty. They were also advised of their Constitutional rights and the consequences of a decision to plead guilty.
